title: Communication
content:
Yup. Got given an old Nokia 3315 for my birthday last year. Before that, people were always wondering where I am--I have a tendency to disappear mysteriously on foot. It's also handy for receiving calls from friends and clients, as well as talking to my girlfriend.

It amuses me how often other people seem to be without credit when they really don't do much more with their phones than I do. $30 has lasted me well over two months.

Messages cost me 1c each to other Telstra phones; calls cost 35c for ten minutes after 9pm, but I'm also given 5c/minute for incoming calls, which means we each end up with 15c more after a 20 minute call.

I must acquire a new one sometime, though. The keypad on this one is starting to become unresponsive, so I keep having to either press really hard for some buttons or pull the phone apart and use a toothpick. Takes me ages to write a message with this thing, whereas on a working phone I can touchtype and punch out a message in no time.

Once I setup this wireless network across town, hopefully I'll be able to get some handheld devices to communicate across it, removing the need to use a phone at all unless I'm abroad.

title: Re: Communication
content:
I had several ones inm my life, but they often got blocked because I didn't use them enough. When I have something to say, I use the normal phone, internet or I just speak to them directly.___________________
DaVince, Yet Another Amateur Game Creator! :P

title: Re: Communication
content:
Nope. I don't talk on a regular phone, and I almost never need to make a call. It'd pretty much be a waste.
(Then again, annoying ringtones and games ARE fun...)-Genius314

title: Re: Communication
content:
Essential. I would never go anywhere or do anything if I couldn't get ahold of my friends from anywhere. I don't even call landlines anymore. They make me a little uncomfortable.________________
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v462/lemur821/toughyorp.png[/img]

title: Re: Communication
content:
As a result of never going out anywhere, I never used to need a phone, but lately I noticed that I seem to be going out into the city or whatever with friends a lot more, and my phone has become a useful tool for keeping in contact if we're not all in the same place.

I still use landlines when I'm at home, though. I'm still too stingy to pay for a mobile phone call when there's an alternative that I'm not paying the bill for.
